title: Quasi-compact morphism
summary: In algebraic geometry, a morphism f : X → Y {\displaystyle f:X\to Y} between schemes is said to be quasi-compact if Y can be covered by open affine subschemes V i {\displaystyle V_{i}} such that the pre-images f − 1 ( V i ) {\displaystyle f^{-1}(V_{i})} are quasi-compact (as topological space).[1] If f is quasi-compact, then the pre-image of a quasi-compact open subscheme (e.g., open affine subscheme) under f is quasi-compact.
